publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

msIdentifier.repository: Bibliothèque nationale de France, fonds Pelliot Koutchéen (Paris)

seg.seg: ... he came out of the house. ... (without?) rest
... the purohita N.N. in the assembly combining combinations pertaining to the sacrifices
... (as) rules doing that completely. Thereupon thousand fell alto(gether)
... the (musical instruments?) ascended over the movable (?) ... Thereupon over the auspicious earth a multi(colored) (shine?)
... they put the individual hairs in the strainers (?) for the ..., the ... (belonging to) the maṇḍala [= ritual circle]
... being (said). Thereupon the white snake ... the squeezed ...
... the ... pertaining to power ... of the ...
... he indeed still relies on the thing. They will quickly do the ..., the big (doers?)
... the clinging ... the lightenings fall down. Because of the fear the great roars in a single direction
... the rainshower oppresses the sky completely, fire flies are to be seen, the voice of animals
... horrible ... are risen, these hurricanes (are) heard in the sky.
... but at that moment the rising of these

p.note: The verse part maybe has the meter 4 x 15 (7/8 or 8/7).

Right part of a large leaf with part of the right margin preserved; recto and verso are unclear; there has been a small piece wrongly placed at the end of lines a 4 and b 3, it has to be turned by 45 degrees.

me is the end of the name of the purohita; the ū either also belongs to this name or is the pronoun (s)ū; telanma is most likely an error for telkanma "sacrifices". The next forms ṣeṃ raitwe cannot be correct either, ṣeṃ should belong to telkanma being the adjectival complement of raitwe; either the anusvara is mistaken, or the form raitwe is a plural.
riyaṃ is certainly the end of a plural form being the subject of the verb; maybe (plo)riyaṃ, pl. of ploriyo "musical instrument".
caranmasa is a perl.pl. of a word car* that is certainly a borrowing from Sanskrit cara- from the root car- "to move"; the precise meaning, however, remains unclear.

rāja- is the start of a color-compound borrowed from Skt. rājavarta- "multicolored", cf. TA rājavartt "id." b3 and a7. It can be restored as rājavat-yok, which is already attested in b 6, but one would rather expect rājavart*, unless the form has been borrowed via Prākrit.

The loc.pl. k[w]alyiṃne is an hapax of the kälymiye-inflection type; this separation is more likely than śk[w]alyiṃne; it may belong to the root kulā- "to recede" referring to a ritual instrument such a a strainer or filter. naś is the end of an allative form. yokaiwenta rather refers to yok 'hair' than to yoko 'drink' (note that filters are made from animal hair), cf. the magical text b5, where yokaiwenta is again used in the context of a Maṇḍala.

kaucciyaṃn(a) is the fem.pl. of an adj. kaucciye*, the meaning of this hapax remains unclear; the form maṇḍāl either has to be restored to the (yet unattested) plural maṇḍālänta (which would mean that the form is an alternant) or to an adj. derived from it.
The segmentation of k(·)ek(·)ä(–) is uncertain; it is either a nominal sentence or a verb, though the latter seems unlikely with respect to the structure of this complex.
yām most likely belongs to a form of the root yām- "to do".

parskalyisa ought to be a perl.sg. of an abstract of the type akalye/āklyi; it is based on the abstract of the subj. V stem parskalñe (with initial accent), the transfer to the akalye/āklyi-inflection may be based on an analogy by replacing the suffix -ñe with -iye; alternatively, the derivation started with the substantivized Ger. parskalye, the suffix of which was restructered as an abstract based on the akalye/āklyi-type. Note that there is at least one other form of this type attested, i.e.wikṣalyisa "through avoidence" in b 4.
khadyotänta is no doubt a loan from Skt. khadyota- “fire fly”.
nirghātänta is no doubt a loan from Skt. nirghāta- “hurricane, earthquake”.

list.item: a1 ... he came out of the house. ... (without?) rest a2 ... the purohita N.N. in the assembly combining combinations pertaining to the sacrifices a3 ... (as) rules doing that completely. Thereupon thousand fell alto(gether) a4 ... the (musical instruments?) ascended over the movable (?) ... Thereupon over the auspicious earth a multi(colored) (shine?) a5 ... they put the individual hairs in the strainers (?) for the ..., the ... (belonging to) the maṇḍala [= ritual circle] a6 ... being (said). Thereupon the white snake ... the squeezed ... b1 ... the ... pertaining to power ... of the ... b2 ... he indeed still relies on the thing. They will quickly do the ..., the big (doers?) b3 ... the clinging ... the lightenings fall down. Because of the fear the great roars in a single direction b4 ... the rainshower oppresses the sky completely, fire flies are to be seen, the voice of animals b5 ... horrible ... are risen, these hurricanes (are) heard in the sky. b6 ... but at that moment the rising of these

Right part of a large leaf with part of the right margin preserved; recto and verso are unclear; there has been a small piece wrongly placed at the end of lines a 4 and b 3, it has to be turned by 45 degrees.

a1 /// – – os(t)meṃ k(e)kamu : – – – – na (snai) l(y)ipär a2 /// (·)ū (– –)me purohite sārrine tel«k»anma«ṣ»ṣeṃ raitwe«nta» rittäskemane|ritäske|(mane) a3 /// ts terinta|tirinta tu po yamaskemane • tumeṃ klānte yaltse ysomo|yso|(mo) a4 /// riyaṃ po caranmasa reṅkare tumeṃ maṅkāläṣṣai keṃ rājavat-yok|rāja|(vat-yok) a5 /// – naś kwalyiṃne yokaiwenta tesare śtwāra kaucciyaṃn(a) maṇḍāl|maṇḍā|(l) a6 /// weweñoṣäṃ|(wew)ñoṣäṃ • tumeṃ ārkwi nāke k(·)ek(·)ä(–) ta(tw)āṅkaṣ (– –) b1 /// cämp(a)mñ(a)ṣṣ(e) ·c· – – m· – – nno – – – – – naṃts /// b2 /// se wäntare|wäntre ykāka ka paktär|pakträ : yāmeṃ ramer pärkwartänta orocceṃ|wrocceṃ yām(·) b3 /// eṅkalñ(e) parśaiṃ kloyontär|kloyoṃträ : parskalyisa newi orocci|wrocci so(mo) kä(l)ymī b4 /// (ka)lsnaṃ ipr(e)r po praśiye|praśye lkālyi khadyotänta lwāsaṃts|lwasāṃts w(e)k mā – (–) b5 /// ·i – – rnta empelona pärkauwa toṃ iprerne nirghātänta klyausentär|klyau|(sentär) b6 /// – – – l·o – – no preśyaine tonaṃts tsäṅkalñe

a1 /// – – [os]·[meṃ k](·)[kamu :] – – – – [na] (–) [l]·[i]_p_a_r\ a2 /// (·)ū (– –)[me] [p]urohite sārrine telanmaṣeṃ raitwe ri[_t_a]ske a3 /// t_s(\) tirinta tu po yamaskemane • tumeṃ klānte ya[lts]e y[so] a4 /// riyaṃ po caranma[s]a reṅkare tumeṃ maṅkā_l_aṣṣai [keṃ] rā[ja] a5 /// – naś k[w]alyiṃne yok[ai]wenta tesare ś[t]wāra kaucciyaṃn(·) maṇḍ[ā] a6 /// – ·[ño]_ṣ_aṃ • tumeṃ [ā]rk[wi] nā[k]e [k](·)e_k(·)_a(–) ta(··)[ā]ṅka_ṣ\ (– –) b1 /// [c]ä[mp](·)mñ(·)ṣṣ(·) ·[c]· – – m· – – nn[o] – – – – – [naṃ]t_s(\) /// b2 /// [se] [wä]ntre ykāka ka pakt[_r_a] : yāmeṃ rame_r\ _p_arkwa[r]_t_anta wrocceṃ yā[m](·) b3 /// [e]ṅkalñ(·) parśaiṃ kloyoṃt_r_a [:] parskalyisa newi wrocci [so] – [_k_a](l)ymī b4 /// ls[n]aṃ i[pr]·r po praśye lkālyi khadyo_t_anta lwasāṃt_s\ [w](·)k m[ā] – (–) b5 /// ·[i] – – [rnta] empel[o]na _p_arkauwa toṃ iprerne ni[rghā]_t_anta klyau b6 /// – – – [l]·[o] – – no p[r]e[ś]yaine tonaṃ[t_s\] t[_s_a]ṅkalñe

b3. parskalyisa ought to be a perl.sg. of an abstract of the type akalye/āklyi; it is based on the abstract of the subj. V stem parskalñe (with initial accent), the transfer to the akalye/āklyi-inflection may be based on an analogy by replacing the suffix -ñe with -iye; alternatively, the derivation started with the substantivized Ger. parskalye, the suffix of which was restructered as an abstract based on the akalye/āklyi-type. Note that there is at least one other form of this type attested, i.e.wikṣalyisa "through avoidence" in [[PK AS 7O]] b 4.
Georges-Jean Pinault (in collaboration with Melanie Malzahn)

The verse part maybe has the meter 4 x 15 (7/8 or 8/7).

a2. me is the end of the name of the purohita; the ū either also belongs to this name or is the pronoun (s)ū; telanma is most likely an error for telkanma "sacrifices". The next forms ṣeṃ raitwe cannot be correct either, ṣeṃ should belong to telkanma being the adjectival complement of raitwe; either the anusvara is mistaken, or the form raitwe is a plural.

a4. riyaṃ is certainly the end of a plural form being the subject of the verb; maybe (plo)riyaṃ, pl. of ploriyo "musical instrument".

a4. caranmasa is a perl.pl. of a word car* that is certainly a borrowing from Sanskrit cara- from the root car- "to move"; the precise meaning, however, remains unclear.

a4. rāja- is the start of a color-compound borrowed from Skt. rājavarta- "multicolored", cf. TA rājavartt "id." [[YQ II.9]] b3 and [[YQ II.10]] a7. It can be restored as rājavat-yok, which is already attested in [[THT 91]] b 6, but one would rather expect rājavart*, unless the form has been borrowed via Prākrit.

a5. The loc.pl. k[w]alyiṃne is an hapax of the kälymiye-inflection type; this separation is more likely than śk[w]alyiṃne; it may belong to the root kulā- "to recede" referring to a ritual instrument such a a strainer or filter. naś is the end of an allative form. yokaiwenta rather refers to yok 'hair' than to yoko 'drink' (note that filters are made from animal hair), cf. the magical text [[PK AS 8C]] b5, where yokaiwenta is again used in the context of a Maṇḍala.

a5. kaucciyaṃn(a) is the fem.pl. of an adj. kaucciye*, the meaning of this hapax remains unclear; the form maṇḍāl either has to be restored to the (yet unattested) plural maṇḍālänta (which would mean that the form is an alternant) or to an adj. derived from it.

a6. The segmentation of k(·)ek(·)ä(–) is uncertain; it is either a nominal sentence or a verb, though the latter seems unlikely with respect to the structure of this complex.

b2. yām most likely belongs to a form of the root yām- "to do".

b4. khadyotänta is no doubt a loan from Skt. khadyota- “fire fly”.

b5. nirghātänta is no doubt a loan from Skt. nirghāta- “hurricane, earthquake”.
Bibliothèque nationale de France, fonds Pelliot Koutchéen (Paris)
